description:
Candidatus Tisiphia endosymbiont of Dioctria linearis is a bacterial endosymbiont species that has been identified within the body of the insect Dioctria linearis, a species of robber fly. Endosymbionts are microorganisms that live in close, often mutually beneficial, relationships with their host organisms.

This endosymbiont species belongs to the Candidatus Tisiphia genus, which is a group of bacteria that have been found in association with various insect hosts. The specific epithet "endosymbiont of Dioctria linearis" denotes its identification as the endosymbiotic partner of the robber fly Dioctria linearis.

While the precise nature of the relationship between Candidatus Tisiphia endosymbiont and its Dioctria linearis host is not fully understood, endosymbionts often play important roles in the physiology, development, or ecology of their insect hosts. Further research may shed light on the specific functions and interactions of this endosymbiotic partnership.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Candidatus Tisiphia endosymbiont of Dioctria linearis
